abstract: Speaking in Conway, S.C., Donald J. Trump said as president he had told NATO allies that he would urge Russian aggression against countries that had not met unofficial financial commitments.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Saturday that, while president, he told the leaders of NATO countries that he would “encourage” Russia “to do whatever the hell they want” to countries that had not paid the money they owed to the military alliance.
headline: Trump Says He Gave NATO Allies Warning: Pay In or He’d Urge Russian Aggression

abstract: Israel has asked the military to come up with plans to evacuate Gazans, but it isn’t clear where they are supposed to go or when Israel’s ground invasion might begin.

abstract: The election of the center-right politician fills a role that is responsible for foreign policy in an era of rising wariness of neighboring Russia.

abstract: A potential expansion of the nation’s military draft to replenish the exhausted, battered army has become an emotional, politically charged issue.

abstract: After four losses, this is the first guild victory for the “Oppenheimer” director. Winners there have won the Academy Award 18 of the last 20 times.

abstract: From England and France to the deepest Arctic and northern China, these stories will transport you.
lead_paragraph: Anne Michaels has served as Toronto’s poet laureate, so it’s no surprise that her latest novel, HELD (Knopf, 240 pp., $27), turns a multigenerational family saga into a lyrical jigsaw of images and observations, a trigger to “the long fuse of memory, always alight.” It begins in the trenches of World War I with a soldier’s impressions of what’s essentially a “450-mile grave” and ends in the near future as one of his descendants walks the streets of a city on the Gulf of Finland.
headline: New Historical Fiction That Immerses You in Far-Flung Places

abstract: Over six terrible months, professors and administrators at Worcester Polytechnic Institute took on the unofficial role of counselors during a spate of campus suicides.
lead_paragraph: The first death happened before the academic year began. In July 2021, an undergraduate student at Worcester Polytechnic Institute was reported dead. The administration sent a notice out over email, with the familiar, thoroughly vetted phrasing and appended resources. Katherine Foo, an assistant professor in the department of integrative and global studies, felt especially crushed by the news. She taught this student. He was Chinese, and she felt connected to the particular set of pressures he faced. She read through old, anonymous course evaluations, looking for any sign she might have missed. But she was unsure where to put her personal feelings about a loss suffered in this professional context.
headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Unthinkable Mental Health Crisis That Shook a New England College’
keywords: Colleges and Universities;Suicides and Suicide Attempts;Medicine and Health;Mental Health and Disorders;Worcester Polytechnic Institute;Massachusetts;New England States (US)

abstract: I used to resent his love for America. Now it’s what I miss most of all.
lead_paragraph: The night before my father, Ronald Reagan, died, I listened to his breathing — ragged, thin. Nothing like that of the athletic man who rode horses, built fences at the ranch, constructed jumps from old phone poles, cut back shrubs along riding trails. Or of the man who lifted his voice to the overcast sky and said, “Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall.”
headline: My Father, Ronald Reagan, Would Weep for America
keywords: United States Politics and Government;Reagan, Ronald Wilson;Presidents and Presidency (US)

abstract: If Biden can’t convince enough voters that he is up to the presidency into his mid-80s, it doesn’t matter how the country feels about Trump.
lead_paragraph: The low approval rating and various political headwinds for President Biden have invited comparisons with another first-term Democratic president, Jimmy Carter, and the challenges he faced running for re-election in 1980. Many Republicans are thinking about his defeat at the hands of Ronald Reagan, bullish that Donald Trump also has what it takes to oust a flagging incumbent.

abstract: With bulgogi-style tofu for Monday and crispy baked fish for Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Many will make chili (above) today, one of the great foods of National Football League cuisine, up there with wings and nachos. Ali Slagle’s recipe is top-drawer: deep in flavor, spice and smokiness, and fairly easy to prepare. I like to make it with coarsely ground beef from the butcher instead of the more finely cut stuff you get at the supermarket, but that’s just me being fancy. Make it with whatever meat you like — so long as it’s decently fatty, to bring out the taste of the aromatics. Chili’s a good way to guarantee a win during the Super Bowl, whichever team you’re rooting for.
headline: Chili for the Championship
keywords: Cooking and Cookbooks;Content Type: Service
